newsitem.title: USA: Mich. legislature adopts $9.2 bln education budget.
newsitem.headline: Mich. legislature adopts $9.2 bln education budget.

text.p: Michigan lawmakers have adopted a $9.2 billion fiscal 1998 budget for elementary and secondary education including a more than $600 million increase in spending.
The overall school funding plan adopted Thursday exceeds Michigan's entire general fund budget for fiscal 1998, the state budget office reported.
Also Thursday, Michigan senators advanced a plan from Treasurer Doug Roberts to create an authority to issue up to $1 billion of debt to fully fund the public school pension system.
The Roberts plan would require districts to waive claims against the state in a funding lawsuit now before the Michigan Supreme Court.
Bonds would be issued only if sufficient numbers of districts and other units adopt a resolution and submit it to the treasurer on or before August 15.
The plan still needs House approval.
The legislature's approved overall spending package addresses any possible costs incurred by the state as a result of the school funding lawsuit as well, the budget office said.

Michigan Gov. John Engler said the budget approval will permit planning for the next year and "commended" lawmakers for addressing the possible costs of the lawsuit that challenged old special education funding practices.
Supreme Court justices ruled for the districts in June and requested additional court filings before determining what compensation, if any, the state must make to them.
The state budget office has estimated that Michigan could face a liability of from $500 million to $3.5 billion in retroactive and future claims from districts statewide.
Lawmakers set the special education budget at $752 million for fiscal 1998 as well in the package to be forwarded to Engler.
Michigan lawmakers are due back in Lansing Tuesday. They have not completed work on a road funding budget or addressed capital outlay requests for fiscal 1998 beginning October 1.
